description:
This PR fixes a couple of issues with the invocation of `off_axis_projection` in the new volume rendering interface. 

* Units were not being returned correctly if you called `off_axis_projection` directly, they were always `"cm"`.  
* If you passed in a `data_source` argument that was a sphere or some other kind of object, it would not be used in the final image but thrown away and replaced with a region object. These changes remove the creation of this second `data_source`. I would like @samskillman to comment on this. 
* We no longer need `OffAxisProjectionFixedResolutionBuffer` to calculate the units because `off_axis_projection` does it correctly now. 

EDIT: Since we can have data containers for sources in off-axis projections now, I'm adding this capability to the `sunyaev_zeldovich` analysis module.
title: [bugfix] Fixing issues with off_axis_projection

content.raw: Are we sure that we don't use this FRB subclass anywhere else?

content.raw: I'm increasingly curious why it was done this way ... I wish I could remember, because there is a great deal of effort expended here to compute the bounding box.
content.html: I'm increasingly curious why it was done this way ... I wish I could remember, because there is a great deal of effort expended here to compute the bounding box.

content.raw: This gets used below; for integration units, is this still correct?  I do not think that it is.
content.html: This gets used below; for integration units, is this still correct? I do not think that it is.

content.raw: I guess I'm not sure what you mean--regardless of where we use it, the behavior of `OffAxisProjectionFixedResolutionBuffer` should be unmodified, because what was taken out of here was put into `off_axis_projection`, which should have been doing it anyway.
content.html: I guess I'm not sure what you mean--regardless of where we use it, the behavior of OffAxisProjectionFixedResolutionBuffer should be unmodified, because what was taken out of here was put into off_axis_projection, which should have been doing it anyway.

content.raw: If you look at what happens below (line 204), we multiply by `dl` with units of `"cm"` to get the integration units if there is no weight field. So actually this is what we should be doing.
content.html: If you look at what happens below (line 204), we multiply by dl with units of "cm" to get the integration units if there is no weight field. So actually this is what we should be doing.

content.raw: I'm inclined to say yes, but I'm persuadable. We get NaNs if we use a weight field with a data source because then we get places where 0/0.
content.html: I'm inclined to say yes, but I'm persuadable. We get NaNs if we use a weight field with a data source because then we get places where 0/0.

content.raw: `max` and `min` operations become problematic if we don't, for instance.

content.raw: @chummels can you have a look at this?
content.html: Cameron Hummels can you have a look at this?

content.raw: I think this was so that the off-axis-projection mimics the volume rendering where rays are only integrated a distance of width[2] along the line of sight. Now that this has a data source explicitly specified, I think this is probably ok this way. Its just that now if you want to project through a disk or something, you specify the disk, rather than the center + widths.
content.html: I think this was so that the off-axis-projection mimics the volume rendering where rays are only integrated a distance of width[2] along the line of sight. Now that this has a data source explicitly specified, I think this is probably ok this way. Its just that now if you want to project through a disk or something, you specify the disk, rather than the center + widths.

content.raw:
I'd be inclined to leave NaN where image[:,:,1] is 0 and image[:,:,0] is nonzero. Perhaps you could fix the case where both are zero with an intermediate

```
#!python
mask = image[:,:,0] == 0
image[:,:,0] /= image[:,:,1]
image[mask] = 0
```
content.html:
I'd be inclined to leave NaN where image[:,:,1] is 0 and image[:,:,0] is nonzero. Perhaps you could fix the case where both are zero with an intermediate

mask = image[:,:,0] == 0
image[:,:,0] /= image[:,:,1]
image[mask] = 0

content.raw: LGTM. Only issue is that if your center/widths don't align with your data source, you'll get empty images. the second region was forcing you to always be integrating data where the camera is. Probably ok. I don't have any comments on the units stuff below since I don't trust my knowledge of unitful ImageArrays. Best verified by tests I would think.

Only issue is that if your center/widths don't align with your data source, you'll get empty images. the second region was forcing you to always be integrating data where the camera is. Probably ok. I don't have any comments on the units stuff below since I don't trust my knowledge of unitful ImageArrays. Best verified by tests I would think.
